instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00840: What is 820-00840? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..

threads.title: PlzBro <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v cycling no 20v
threads.message:
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>
Liquid Damage
Liquid was around and down both USB C charging Circuits and controllers
Cleaned area and found 5 burnt traces
Burnt traces
<RESISTOR>R3351</RESISTOR> Burnt <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> pad - Ran jumper to <RESISTOR>R3451</RESISTOR> <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> side and replaced <RESISTOR>R3351</RESISTOR> with new 10K resistor
<RESISTOR>R3360</RESISTOR> Burn via - Cleaned and checked continuity to resistor and output and has continuity
PIN 46/55 of <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> (<SIGNAL>TP_NC_UDP_XA_SWD_CLK</SIGNAL>) Test point burnt off board but BRD shows this goes no where. When Charger plugged in these lines are both 3.3v
PIN 55 of <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> (<SIGNAL>TSP_USP_XB_SWD_CLK</SIGNAL>) Test point burnt off board. Line reads 3.3v when charger is plugged in

<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is 3.368v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 5v and cycles 0-5v every few seconds as if there is some type of reset. 

<CHIP>U3100</CHIP> and <CHIP>U3200</CHIP> were clean when pulled and no burnt pads under the chip or corrosion. Reballed and reinstalled and no change.
I am ordering new ICs but was wondering if Im missing something else since the chips had no signs of liquid under them.

threads.title: PlzBro <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v cycling no 20v
threads.message:
<CHIP>U3100</CHIP>/200 have firmware; no way to put new ones.
Must pick them from donor board; not identical model, but chips code termination should be the same (i.e A03, C01).

"<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 5v and cycles 0-5v every few seconds"
For sure, isn't <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL>?
However, check for short between <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: PlzBro <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v cycling no 20v
threads.message:
No short between <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> with charger plugged in is 5.12v constant 
Now <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 0v and voltage on the Coils <SIGNAL>USBC_X_CC1</SIGNAL>, etc are bouncing around 1-2v

threads.title: PlzBro <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v cycling no 20v
threads.message: 5v at the Fuses by <TRANSISTOR>Q3100</TRANSISTOR>/200 which cycles every few seconds

threads.title: PlzBro <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v cycling no 20v
threads.message:
You got too much corrosion on USB-C controllers area.
There could be some traces inside board affected too.

Check for short D-S all 4 MOSFETs from <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR>/40.
Also check voltage and diode mode for all LDO from <CHIP>U3100</CHIP>/200.

threads.title: PlzBro <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v cycling no 20v
threads.message: If you for sure have no corrosion near the CPU fets, this sounds to me like bad CD3215s especially if <SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> is present. Do a diode mode of all the LDO lines near both chips 3v3 1v8 etc and compare

threads.title: PlzBro <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v cycling no 20v
threads.message:
I'm at home right now but before I left I checked 3v3out 1v1 ldo 1v8 ldo and some other power rails around those chips 

1v1 was 1.08-1.1v
1v8 was 1.79v
3v3 out was 3.29v
??????there was one other 3v3 line that was also 3.29v
the ldo voltages I believe were only present on 1 chip at a time dependent on which USB C port was plugged. Which makes sense. 
I guess what I'm failing to understand here is what OKs the switch from 5v to 20v. Is this all inside the two TI ICs?
???

threads.title: PlzBro <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v cycling no 20v
threads.message: Not sure why my phone posted a million question marks. Sorry about that lol

threads.title: PlzBro <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00840</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5v cycling no 20v
threads.message:
SMC should talk with charger, in order to enable 20V.
So all USB-C controllers must be OK.
